intro: Lappula stipitata, commonly known as the common lappula, is an annual herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. It typically grows to a height of 20–60 cm, featuring slender, branched stems covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, pale yellow flowers arranged in clusters, which bloom from late spring to early summer. Its leaves are alternate, ovate to lanceolate, and often have a slightly hairy texture. Lappula stipitata thrives in moist, disturbed soils and is often found along roadsides, in meadows, and near water bodies.
